Eurydice is pleased that your people are happy and devout.

May the Muses sing your praises, Eurydice, Queen and Caretaker of Macedon. The fate of the kingdom falls to you: your descendants are destined for future greatness, but face dire threats here and now. There are those that seek to overthrow you and your family; you must stop them - no matter the costs. Look for friendly faces at home and abroad for aid and be bold, for the spirit of Eucleia burns brightly within you.

Eurydice
Queen of Macedon

Eurydice I was the wife of King Amyntas III. She is believed to have been of Lyncestian ancestry, although writers such as Plutarch hold that she was Illyrian. Eurydice, with Amyntas, had three sons - Alexander II, Perdiccas III, and Philip II - all of whom would become King of Macedon. She was also the grandmother of Alexander the Great.

Eurydice was born between 410 and 404 BCE to a noble named Sirras. She married Amyntas in her 20s, probably as a diplomatic attempt to secure peace between Macedon and her people. Amyntas's rule was tumultous; Greek Chalcidians took a large portion of the kingdom, including Pella, until Sparta intervened. Nevertheless, Eurydice was able to supplant Amyntas's primary wife Gygaea to assume the title of Queen. Amyntas III died c. 370 BCE and the kingdom soon began to experience grave troubles. Eurydice's first son, Alexander II took the throne but was killed 2 years later by Ptolemy of Aloros; an agreement worked out by Theban statesman Pelopidas preserved some Macedonian sovereignty, as Ptolemy became regent for Eurydice's two other sons. To protect them, Eurydice married Ptolemy. During Ptolemy's regency for Perdiccas, a noble named Pausanias attempted to usurp the throne. Eurydice asked for help from the Athenian general Iphicrates, who succeeded in driving out Pausanias. Eurydice's bold action likely saved the kingdom and was an extraordinary act for a woman at this time. For this and other reasons, Eurydice's reign is often believed to have marked a turning point in the role of women in Macedon.

Eurydice was very much involved in the affairs of state and the culture of Macedon. She is believed to have funded the construction of a temple dedicated to Eucleia, the female spirit of glory, at Vergina. She is also believed to have learned to read and write late in her life - a talent she believed was a gift of the Muses. The date of her death is unknown, but it is believed to have been between 365 and 359 BCE, meaning that she probably died before seeing her youngest son, Philip II, assume the throne. Philip and his descendants did not forget about Eurydice, however; her portrait-statue was included as part of the Philippeion at Olympia, built to commemorate Philip's victory at the Battle of Chaeronea in 338 BCE. Though little is solidly known about the life of Eurydice, her valor and bravery outlived her. Aeschines considered her to be a loyal defender of her sons, and Plutarch wrote that she was a model to emulate when educating children.

Eurydice's greatest strengths lie in her relationships with her allies. If you can isolate her diplomatically, her advantages will crumble. Be wary, however, for though she may seem to be more oriented towards defense, Macedonian troops can still pack quite the punch!

As Eurydice, your greatest advantage is unlocked midway through civics tree at Civil Service, which unlocks alliances; unlocking this civic should be a priority for you. Before reaching the medieval era, try to cultivate friendships with nearby civs that you can then elevate into alliances. Also feel free to try and pursue a religion in the early game; with the bonus science from Holy Site buildings, focusing on early religion won't be as punishing for you as it might be for other leaders.
Welcome, stranger, to Macedon. I am Eurydice, Queen of these lands and a faithful servant of the goddess Eucleia.
Would you care to visit one of our cities? Come, spend some time at one of our many temples! Perhaps the gods will smile upon you.
A kind gesture - I shall leave at once, just as soon as I get someone to look after my sons...
I'd like to know where I can find you in the event an emergency rises, and of course I would offer up my home to you in turn. What say you?
Ah, you've returned.
I welcome them with open arms - it'll be nice to have to some friendly faces around here.
Our current diplomatic relations are too... complicated... at the moment for me to allow this.

Please accept the gifts I have dispatched to your capital. You will find I have sent fine jewelry, some poetry blessed by the Muses, and some of my favorite wine, along with a krater of course - one can't have a symposium without that!
Your troops' presence here could help defend against any upstart pretenders. I accept.
Ha! So that you can stir up dissent within my borders? I think not!
The gods have blessed this world with great beauty, please allow my people safe passage through your lands so that they may know the work of the divine ones.
Of course! May Eucleia smile upon this bond.
I'm afraid not.
Some people choose to see the ugliness in this world, the disarray. But I choose to see the beauty, and there is beauty in friendship, don't you think?
Wonderful!.
Oh, perhaps I misjudged. My apologies.
There is strength in numbers; a strength that will ensure the continuation of my family's rule. Will you join me - for the sake of my sons if nothing else
You rule over your subjects with the love of a parent, and the gods have blessed your people with gifts for their faith. I commend you wholeheartedly.
Do you ever stop to wonder about your actions? Your threatening posture? Your godlessness? You will pay a dear price when the gods make their will known.
Watch where your troops wander - I will not hestitate to defend Macedon and my family.
A fine proposal.
I cannot accept this.
Your threatening words shall not intimidate me. Macedon will stand strong despite your incivility.
The world must know of your godless ways, for we must stand united against your military provocations (Denounces You).
(You have a stronger army and have low faith production)
So it has come to this. You stain the beauty of this world with your violence. May the gods give me strength to defend against your aggressions.
This world... There is something wrong with this world: you. You will lie with the rest of your kind in the dirt. Your dreams forgotten, your horrors effaced.
Macedon welcomes this cessation of hostilies. I pray that peace's reign will be long and prosperous.
No. These violent delights have violent ends.
Perhaps there is still a chance for progress, for prosperity, for peace?
Everyone I've cared about is gone. The pain, their loss - it's all I have left of them, but I'm not crying for myself; I weep for the world.
